It's a simple pleasure that's hard to resist.  I've been known to enjoy a bowl of this on a cold night, and it always hits the spot.  It's a great option for a quick and easy meal, and it's

prompt.content: You are an Amazon customer that likes to write reviews for products. You will be provided a set of features to help you understand your writing style. First feature you will receive is similar product-review pairs from your past reviews to remind you of your style: Product: Kraft Grated Parmesan Cheese, 16-Ounce Plastic Canister (Pack of 3) Review: Parmesan is known as the queeen of Italian cheese. Kraft Grated Parmesan, 16-Ounce Plastic Canister (Pack of 3). Kraft Grated Parmesan cheese has been around since 1945. The container has been updated, but the cheese is still the queen. There are more delicious variations, such as freshly grated . . . and now Kraft has a kind with the grater included so we can grate our cheese to serve it fresh. I still buy large amounts of the good basic grated parmesan in the refillable green shaker container. It is quick, and most people are in a hurry these days. It will keep if we leave it on the table when we eat at the cafeteria. Ususally at home, I keep it in the refrigerator. It is great for a wide range of dishes, including pastas, soups, sauce, snack, bread, and meat. With only ten calories per teaspoon, we can sprinkle on all we want without feeling guilty. The cheese taste is one I crave, and eating Kraft's Parmesan is a good way to satisfy that craving for cheese. Perhaps parmesan cheese has been around since the eighth century B. C. or was it developed about 400 years ago in in the Italian city of Parma? There was a story that near Parma there was a mountain made entirely of parmesan cheese. On top of the mountain a community of macaroini makers cooked hot pasta, bathed it in butter, and rolled it down the mountain to the hungry people below. There is a legend that it was used by Roman legionniares becaue it lasted throughout their long journeys. (I found these stories on Kraft websites, and I could not resist sharing them with you.) Some of our recipes in Flavored with Love: Mary Lou's Family and Friends Can Cook and The Collard Patch call for large amounts of Kraft Parmesan. At my house we use Kraft Parmesan cheese in lasagna, meatballs, collard tortellini, and casseroles containing collard greens! It's delicious. I hope you found this review helpful. Rating: 5.0 Product: Suddenly Pasta Salad, Creamy Parmesan, 6.2-Ounce Boxes (Pack of 12) Review: We like the ranch and bacon flavor, but it is not what we usually think of when we think pasta salad. We think of something more Italian than ranch when we have pasta. Try it, though. You may love it if you are fond of ranch flavors. Rating: 4.0 Product: Healthy Choice Lunch Express, Italian Style Penne 6.95-Ounce Bowls (Pack of 6) Review: We enjoyed Healthy Choice Fresh Mixers, Zita & Meat Sauce. My friend and I are spicemouths, and we found the mixers decently flavored, perhaps better than some dishes we've tried in Italian restaurants that needed to fire their cooks. We eat in many different restaurants throughout the United States to evaluate the food. What we have discovered is that mediocre food can be made tasty if we apply our emergency taste-enhancer kit. Actually this dish was better than mediocre; in fact it was tasty, especially after we added some items from the kit. (We keep an array of items in our glove compartments of our vehicles and on our breakfast bar.) Realizing that we did not want to alter the calorie-count too much, we added a tiny shake of Kraft Grated Parmesan Cheese - 4.5 lb. container, which was about 10 calories. When we eat pasta, we like a little cheese. Then, being the way we are -- Louisiana and Texas people -- we needed a little kick. We shook on a few flakes of crushed red. (Tone's Spices Red Pepper Crushed (13.5 oz) - Large Restaurant / Food Service Size Shaker Container - Best Value per Ounce-- we really do buy the large restaurant shaker, but we carry a smaller version around with us in the car.) That's all we added, although we do have other items in our emergency supplies. With those two little items, the ziti and meat sauce tasted good. Preparing it was fun. The cute little container with the strainer lid amused me. I thought I would wash it and reuse it, but I was amazed to discover it was engineered for single use. This meal of 340 calories was satisfying and handled our hunger efficiently. It contains 600 mg sodium, which is perhaps a little less than some prepared dishes. I was surprised to see that it contains 990 mg potassium. People with renal disease should probably avoid this product unless they have the approval of their physician or registered dietician. There are 6 grams of total fat and 56 carb grams. With 8 grams of dietary fiber, it should get an approving nod from Weight Watchers. It meets the criteria established by the American Heart Association. I would recommend this dish for anyone who needs to take lunch to work where there is no refrigerator but where there is a microwave oven. I thought we would eat it again soon, but weeks have passed and we are still thinking about it. Mostly recommended. Mary Lou Cheatham, co-author of THE COLLARD PATCH/ Author of FLAVORED WITH LOVE, SOLOMON'S PORCH, DO YOU KNOW HOW GOD LOVES YOU? Rating: 4.0 Product: Sun Maid California Raisins, 12-Ounce Pouches (Pack of 6) Review: We like raisins (Sun Maid Raisins, 12-Ounce Bags (Pack of 6)), and if you knew how many we eat, you would be shocked. We eat them on our cold cereal, in our oatmeal, mixed with almonds, stirred up with peanut butter, and by themselves. They are good to eat and good for people. They are pure food . . . "grapes and sunshine" Sun-Maid calls them. They are made in California's San Joaquin Valley from Thompson Seedless grapes. One pound of raisins is 4 pounds of fresh grapes. The hot summer sun makes the grapes sweet and juicy. In addition to snacking on raisins, we like to cook with them. Here's a classic recipe using raisins. My sister Ruth won a prize with it in a cooking show, and she shared it with permission in Flavored with Love: Mary Lou's Family and Friends Can Cook. Ruth's Prize-Winning Broccoli Salad 4 cups broccoli cup raisins cup onion cup nuts cup celery cup real bacon bits cup light mayonnaise cup sugar cup vinegar (apple cider or white) Mix the first 6 ingredients. Make a sauce out of the mayonnaise, sugar, and vinegar. Pour the sauce over the salad. Toss and chill. Lately we are paying more attention to nutrition. Raisns have 130 calories in a 1/4 cup serving. There are condensed food. They contain no fat. They have natural sugar with a large carbohydrate load. One serving has almost no sodium but 310 mg potassium. Diabetics and renal patients should consult with their dieticians before including raisins in their diets. I hope you enjoy Ruth's recipe and find this review helpful. Rating: 5.0 Product: HERSHEY'S Baking Cocoa, SPECIAL DARK Hot Cocoa, 8 Ounce (Pack of 6) Review: This box of the most magnificent flavor in the world -- Hershey's Cocoa (Hershey's Cocoa, Natural Unsweetened, 8-Ounce Can (Pack of 6))-- contains the secret of my favorite childhood food memories. My mother could take a box of Hershey's Cocoa and produce a wonderland of culinary treasures. My brother and I convinced her that we could not drink milk unless it was hot cocoa. She wanted us to drink milk; so she made us hot cocoa. She taught me how to do it when I was quite young. The cake! She could make an old-fashioned chocolaty chocolate cake with the fudge frosting that she could make perfectly by cooking it until it was in a soft-ball stage. We found a cake like that at a church bake sell this week. Awww! So good! The candy, the brownies, chocolate pudding . . . her food was marvelous all because of the good old-fashioned cocoa. Many members of my family and many of my friends love Hershey's cocoa too. Is there any other brand? Here's a neat little recipe that is hard to find these days. This one, along with several others, is in Flavored with Love: Mary Lou's Family and Friends Can Cook. A friend gave it to me, and Paul and I cooked it on a local early morning television show. Chocolate Drops 2 cups sugar cup cocoa (Hershey's, of course!) cup evaporated milk 1 stick margarine cup peanut butter 2 teaspoons vanilla 3 cups minute oats Bring the mixture to a rolling boil and let it boil for 1 minute. Drop by teaspoons onto waxed paper. Adding 1/2 cup of toasted pecans enhances the texture and taste of these delicious cookies. I'm very glad that Amazon has started stocking this product. It is an American classic. I always have it in my kitchen. The ingredient in this fantastic box is cocoa, and cocoa is healthy. There are 20 calories in 1 tablespoon. It contains fiber, carbohydrates, and fat. There are always foolproof recipes on the box. Get yourself some Hershey's cocoa and savor it. Rating: 5.0 Product: Mr. Z Premium Cuts Beef Jerky Sweet & Hot Flavor, 1-Ounce Bags (Pack of 12) Review: Mr. Z Premium Cuts Beef Jerky Sweet & Hot Flavor, 1-Ounce Bags (Pack of 12) -- Oh, how delicious! These disappeared quickly at my house. They're sweet enough and not too hot, not at all too hot. The only problem is that they cost a bit more than I think they should. These are great for traveling, snacking, and recrational eating. They're ideal for low carb, high protein diets. I enjoyed the taste very much! Rating: 5.0 Product: Pasta Roni Garlic & Olive Oil Vermicelli Mix (Pack of 12 Boxes) Review: Pasta Roni Garlic & Olive Oil Vermicelli Mix, 4.6-Ounce Boxes (Pack of 12) is a delicious meal for two. I sauteed them in the olive oil before adding the water and packaged ingredients. Then I looked in Flavored with Love: Mary Lou's Family and Friends Can Cook at Mike's Ma's Lasagna and found the meatball recipe there. Yum! With meatballs, it was quite a dish. golds.output: I've been managing my blood sugar for a while now, and I've tried a few different shakes to help keep things in check.  This Glucerna shake is a solid option, especially if you're looking for a convenient way to get some extra nutrients. prompt.content:
You are an Amazon customer that likes to write reviews for products. You will be provided a set of features to help you understand your writing style.
First feature you will receive is similar product-review pairs from your past reviews to remind you of your style:
<similarpairs>
Product:
Boost Calorie Smart 100 Calories, Balanced Nutritional Drink, Vanilla Caramel, 4 Fluid Ounce (Pack of 4)(16 Bottles Total)
Review:
Anyone out there remember Metrecal?  It was a liquid meal sold as a diet aid.  Four cans a day @ 225 calories a can was supposed to be a full day's nutrition.  Metrecal was the first thing I thought of when I tasted Boost 100.  So I got curious and went to look up Metrecal which has been off the market since the mid-70s.  From what I can gather the ingredients are roughly the same, skim milk powder, soy protein, oil, vitamins and minerals.  Since both Boost and Metrecal have their roots in nutritional supplements for people who can't have a solid diet for whatever reason, it stands to reason that if it worked then, it's still going to work.  And in fact that combination delivers a solid 10 grams of protein in each bottle, plus vitamins, minerals, some carbs and fats.  It's a solid nutritional supplement with the added benefit of being low in calories

Now if you look up Metrecal online you'll see all sorts of hand-waving about how awful it tasted.  While I think that's mostly hyperbole from people who probably never even tasted the stuff,  I'm not going to try to tell you it was the best thing since Cherry Garcia ice cream.  It wasn't and neither is Boost 100.  It's drinkable, nothing more.  It's not a treat, but it won't make you gag.  The advantage to Boost is the nutrition.  If, for whatever reason, your diet isn't giving you enough nutrition, then this may help  Personally I have a lot of trouble getting enough protein in my diet, so Boost is something that I may use on a regular basis.  Not enthusiastically, mind you, but because it's one of the better choices.

Bottom line, it's probably as good as any other convenient nutritional supplement.  I think it's a bit pricey at a bit over $2 a bottle, but if you don't use more than one a day, it's not not a bad investment in your health.
Rating:
3.0
Product:
Thai Kitchen Coconut Milk, 13.66 fl oz (Pack of 12)
Review:
Of all the coconut milk I've tried, Thai Kitchen seems to give me the best flavor and consistency.  It's good in curries, in baking, whipped as an alternative to whipped cream (you have to have the full fat version for this, not the lite), and even in smoothies.  Normally it's kind of expensive, but the price here on Amazon comes to just under $1.45 per can which is a great price.  Always assuming you can buy in bulk that is.

If you do use a lot of this stuff, Amazon is probably your best resource.
Rating:
5.0
Product:
Wholesome Sweeteners Organic Fair Trade Honey, 16-Ounce Bottles (Pack of 3)
Review:
Organic and fair trade are two designations I like to see on products I buy. Together they're nearly irresistible, but of course a lot depends on whether the product is worth buying.  Does it taste good?  Wholesome Sweeteners honey does taste good.  It's a dark amber honey with the kind of slight bitterness you find in buckwheat honey.  It also has an odd flavor, probably because I'm unused to honey produced from South American plants.  Not unappealing, just different.

If you can find something like this that suits your tastes and covers a lot of socio-political bases as well, why not buy it?
Rating:
5.0
Product:
India Tree Dark Muscovado Sugar, 1 Pound (Pack of 6)
Review:
This is possibly the best-tasting dark brown sugar I've ever used.  It has a dark, molasses-y flavor that raises baked goods to a special level.  Now clearly it's not for everyone and everything, but if you have a recipe that can stand up to the heady flavor of molasses, and if you love that musky bitter-sweetness, then give this a  try.  I think you'll find it complex, warm and welcoming.
Rating:
5.0
Product:
Rice Select Royal Blend, Whole Grain Texmati Brown & Wild Rice with Soft Wheat & Rye Berries, 28 oz Jars (Pack of 4)
Review:
In an attempt to make my diet less dependent upon simple carbs, I've been shopping for whole grain products that don't taste like sand, cardboard or twigs and pebbles.  RiceSelect has come up with a clear winner with this blend of three different grain products: Two types of rice, barley and rye.  It has a warm, comforting quality, good flavor and is just loaded with the kind of fiber we all need.  You could do a lot worse and believe me, I have.

Try cooking it in stock or broth and adding just a touch of butter and salt.  I make mine in my rice cooker (If you eat a lot of grains, get one.  Trust me on this, you'll thank me in the end.  Zojirushi makes some of the best.) and it's a nearly no-fuss operation.  Ingredients in, cooker on, walk away.  Come back to an amazing meal.
Rating:
5.0
Product:
Peanut Butter & Co. Vanilla Peanut Powder, Non-GMO Project Verified, Gluten Free, Vegan, 6.5 oz Jar
Review:
I've tried several PB powders in an effort to add protein and flavor to smoothies.  Mostly the result is iffy because, of course, when you take the fat out of food, you're removing the thing which conveys flavor.  You can up the flavor stakes by adding a whole lot more of the PB powder to whatever it is you're making, or you can add some sugar which is a flavor intensifier.  That's what's Peanut Butter & Company has done here.  A normal serving adds enough flavor to my smoothies that I'm satisfied.

I don't much like the powder mixed into a butter, but that's not why I bought it.  In the final analysis I got what I wanted, but it does come at a substantially higher price than using plain peanut butter and a sprinkle of cocoa, so it's a trade-off.  Ultimately I may just opt to use this as an additive in baking and go back to a spoonful of real peanut butter in my smoothie.
Rating:
4.0
Product:
V8 Healthy Greens, 12 oz. Bottle (Pack of 12)
Review:
I decided to give this a shot under the most demanding circumstances.  I poured myself a glass out of a room-temperature bottle.  If it was palatable like that, it would be fine cold, or mixed into smoothies and such.  And on my first sip I made a really unpleasant noise, at least in part because the flavor is so dramatically different from the aroma.  It smells strongly of green apples, but the flavor is very far from anything like that.  My first thought?  Ugh.

But frequently first impressions are wrong, and I kept drinking, a bit at a time.  And as I did, I grew used to the flavor fairly quickly and found that, while it wasn't insanely delicious, it was good enough for what it was, a blend of fruit and vegetables to help get what, for most people, is much-needed nutrition.  Americans don't eat enough fruits and vegetables, and if this gets some of those nutrients into us, then yay, good on V8.

Is it as good for you as a piece of fruit or a serving of veggies?  Heck no!  For one thing there's nearly no fiber in this juice -- a single gram per serving -- and fiber is one of the more important things you get out of produce.  You can, if you're so inclined, add fiber with any one of the bazillion fiber supplements on the market.  I don't think it's a patch on a fresh nectarine or a plate of carrot sticks, but it'll do.  And it has a reasonable amount of vitamins, mostly C.

So the bottom line here is that this isn't a great substitute for fresh produce by any stretch, but if you cannot or will not eat fresh produce, at least it's something.  The flavor is okay, it'll make a good base for smoothies, or be reasonably drinkable out of the fridge or even on the rocks.  Not going to be my favorite thing ever, but I could honestly say that about anything that's not ice cream.
Rating:
3.0
</similarpairs>

Review:
Believe it or not, these canned tomatoes make an awesome salsa! Beats the heck out of making it with those straw-flavored "fresh" tomatoes from the grocery store! Also beats the store bought salsas hands down, with the added advantage that you can put into your salsa exactly what you want. I drain the tomatoes in a colander, give a few pulses of a stick blender, and add 1 large chopped onion, four or so jalapeno or serrano peppers (seeded), a handful of chopped cilantro, a little chopped parsley, juice of a lime, and a little bit of sea salt . . . or not. Tastes great without salt, but a little bit doesn't seem to bother me. This is so easy to make a l-o-o-o-t of salsa with, too -- like for parties.  And that strained off juice? Sure tastes great as a drink! Keeps really well in a cold fridge, in a jar or air-tight container.

I think their recipe must have changed. Probably cost-cutting. The following may explain why the recipe has changed.

From: [...]

Bruce Foods first marketed Louisiana Hot Sauce in 1928,[3][5] and manufactured the product through April 2015.[4] It started off as a family company, in which the sauce was prepared in the kitchen of a home and sold to neighbors.[5] Louisiana Hot Sauce was the first sauce brand marketed using the state of Louisiana's name.[a] The brand's slogan is "not too hot, not too mild."[1]

In April 2015, Bruce foods sold the Louisiana Hot Sauce brand and its assets to Southeastern Mills Inc., which is based in the U.S. state of Georgia.[4] The hot sauce continues to be made at the manufacturing plant in New Iberia, Louisiana.[4] Louisiana Hot Sauce and other brands operated "under the company name The Original Louisiana Hot Sauce Co."[4]

My granddaughter invited me to share her snack. One taste and I asked for more! These are the most delicious snack I have had in a long time. After she went to bed, her father and I shared the rest of the box. I replaced the box the next day, and in ought a box to bring home.

There are no Artificial Flavors, Synthetic Colors or Synthetic Preservatives. No antibiotics, hormones or pesticides. The cheese is real organic cheese, and boy, does it taste good. Of course, this is more expensive than the boxes of chemicals you can purchase at the grocery store. However, when purchasing via Amazon the price is cheaper, if you have Prime, no postage at all.

I cannot recommend this organic snack enough. The perfect treat for for child or grand child's class.

Product:
Paleo Apricot Strawberry Energy Bars - Gluten-Free, Soy-Free, Dairy-Free, non-GMO Certified - Vegan, Raw, Kosher - Kid-School Safe Snack - Clean fuel for athletes - Pack of 12 bars by Amrita
Review:
My son-in-law has many food sensitivities, and I thought I might give him some of my samples, but I ended up eating them all. I will purchase the 12 pack for him. I am always bringing my granddaughter and daughter any treat, and now instead of fruit I can give him these.

I was quite surprised how good these Amrita Bars are. Usually gluten free leaves me a little cold with the consistency, but these are made with a paste, so the taste and consistency are very high quality. The brown rice and date paste which are the base give these bars a very good taste. As with most reviewers I preferred the mango/coconut, chocolate maca and the pineapple chia. However, all of them are tasty. I brought the apricot/strawberry with me this afternoon when I went grocery shopping. I usually stop for a coffee and bun, but today only coffee and this bar. It was quite filling, tasted good with the coffee, a little sweet but the coffee tempered that for me. I am very pleased to be eating such a healthy bar, beside the better nutritional value and the lower calories, it tastes so good. I feel like I am being well rewarded for my choices. Note: complimentary product was provided for review.

Recommended. prisrob 02-17-15

Product:
Progresso Soup, Traditional, Homestyle Chicken Soup, 19 oz Cans (Pack of 6)
Review:
Progress makes a delicious line of soups, my favorites are tomato with basil and the chicken noodle. Today I decided to try the Split Pea with ham.

The split pea is one of the better canned soups I have tried. It is made with with split peas, ham, carrots, potatoes and celery. There are no artificial flavors and no colors from artificial sources. One can will give you on average 1.5 servings. There are 130 mg calories per serving which is a very good deal. The deal breaker is that there is also 690mg of sodium. This is equal to 30% of our daily recommended value. We eat too much sodium, and this soup should be a once in awhile Soup. Otherwise eat your fill, and have another bowl at a much later date,

Pure Leaf is brewed from real tea leaves, and you can tell by the taste. it is sweetened with real sugar, nothing artificial. The lemon adds that little bit of tartness. This iced tea is perfect for entertaining or home.

I like grits with a bit of cheddar cheese,salt, pepper and butter. They are delicious anytime, but I particularly like them with sausage and eggs. Quaker is a well known name for oats and grits. Easy to make, the perfect accompaniment for any meal. No salt, no cholesterol and few calories.

1. This is not just Stevia- it has another raw sugar in it called cain sugar which gives 1.2g of sugar and 1.2g of total carbs and 5calories per serving- so be aware diabetics.

Cane sugar (raw sugar) is sucrose which has been extracted from sugarcane, a tropical plant which produces naturally high concentrations of this sweet substance. No one will claim that sugar is good for you, but raw sugar is more healthful than refined sugar because there are no chemical additives. Raw sugar is minimally processed, making it a natural product and easier for your body to digest. All sugar is high in calories and low in

2. Now the Sweetleaf in the packets (THIS PRODUCT) has Inulin and Stevia Extract- the inulin which gives the fiber- so this has less than 1g of fiber- zero carbs zero sugar listed and zero calories per serving.

Inulin is a polysaccharide that is produced by plants such as onions, leeks, Jerusalem artichokes, and garlic. It can also be referred to as neosugar, alant starch, Alantin, and diabetic sugar. Many manufacturers are putting it in processed foods because it has tremendous health benefits. It can also be used to replace higher calorie ingredients such as fat, sugar, and flour. However, there is also some controversy about how much it should be used.
There are many ways that plants store energy for themselves, with inulin being one of them. As such, it can be found in the roots and rhizomes of many plants. When eaten, this substance does not increase blood sugar, which makes it an option for those with diabetes.
There are many benefits of inulin. It has one-third to one-fourth less food energy than that of sugar and a sixth to a ninth less energy than fat. It is also a soluble fiber which means that when it passes through the body, it creates a gel. Since fiber is not digested in the human body, it passes through to the intestine largely intact. There, it feeds the good bacteria that live there. It also helps to reduce the absorption of bad cholesterol in the body.

3. Stevia in the Raw has "less than 1g of both sugar and carbs- ingredients are Dextrose and stevia leaf extract- however zero cal per serving

Dextrose is an organic compound.. It is manufactured naturally in the human body from the breakdown of mainly carbohydrates, but also proteins and fats. Dextrose is the result of photosynthesis in plants and is found in concentrated amounts in fruits and honey. This white, sweet, crystalline substance can be produced synthetically from starch. The names dextrose and glucose are often used interchangeably, but it is important to note the difference. Glucose has several molecular forms. Dextrose is the biologically active form and is very common in plant and animal life.

Stevia is a word both for a plant and for a sweetener extracted from the leaves of that plant. stevia is much sweeter than other sugars, meaning that only a small amount needs to be used. The body also processes stevia very slowly, which greatly reduces the risk of a sugar high. it is essentially calorie free, which is why it is popular with dieters. it may be safe for diabetics, but diabetics should always consult their doctors about additions to their diet which may alter their blood sugar.

prompt.content: You are an Amazon customer that likes to write reviews for products. You will be provided a set of features to help you understand your writing style. First feature you will receive is similar product-review pairs from your past reviews to remind you of your style: Product: Stevia Select Stevia Powder-Organic Stevia-100% Pure Stevia Extract-No Fillers-1 Oz Stevia from the Sweet Leaf-Perfect Weight Loss Diet Aid-Natural Sweetener-Great Tasting Stevia Guarantee! Review: A TRUE REPLACEMENT After 60 years, I've broken my sugar addiction. Before pure Stevia, I used Splenda and later Truvia/Purevia (Stevia cut with bulking agents) for several years. The Truvia/Purevia were better than Splenda, but both the Splenda and Truvia/Purevia left disgusting residues and just didn't taste right (because of the fillers or bulking agents added). More importantly for me, I could not fully enjoy my gourmet coffee with either. When I first began using pure Stevia, I appreciated the better flavor and lack of a residue, but it still did not taste quite like sugar to me. However, after a few months, Stevia tasted like sugar to me, and I could again enjoy gourmet coffee. In short, there is an adjustment period. Perhaps more precisely, pure stevia is "as effective" as sugar for "cutting the edge" of bitter or sour drinks and foods---the way most people use sugar. However, it is not as "lusciously" sugary-sweet as sugar, regardless of how much you use. For a rare, once-a-month "desert" cup of fine coffee, I still use real sugar and real cream. For lemonade and other very sour drinks, Splenda tastes better than stevia, to me. For years I used KAI PURE STEVIA---until they started adulterating in. Then I tried another Chinese brand which claimed to be pure, but was "diluted" with some sort of filler. I'm not sure this "Select Stevia" is quite as sweet as the original KAI, but it is the best brand currently available that I've found. MEASUREMENT One "tiny spoon" (included) of STEVIA POWDER = 1 teaspoon of sugar. The 1 oz jars are more convenient than the 3.5 oz jars, because the included "tiny spoon" can reach to nearly the bottom of the jars. It is hard to get near the bottom of the larger jars. RECOMMENDATION A rubber band (ideally a fat "broccoli" rubber band) is ideal for holding the "tiny spoon" to the side of the bottle. A paperclip makes a good permanent tab for lifting the rubber band to insert the spoon. WHEN TRUVIA OR PURVIA MIGHT BE A BETTER CHOICE > I carry packets of Truvia with me when I travel by air, because I do not want to take the chance on being detained to explain loose white powder to TSA/DEA agents. > There is really no effective way to sprinkle pure stevia over fruit, etc. it is just too concentrated. Truvia/Purvia or Splenda are better for such uses. Indeed, if you regularly sweeten your coffee with pure stevia near your cutting board, you are likely to find all kinds of odd things, such as sweet broccoli, having been sweetened by the invisible residue of escaped stevia. IS NATURAL BETTER? Not necessarily. The most toxic and carcinogenic substances known are "natural". In fact, most "flavorful" natural compounds, including most spices and herbs, are created by plants as insect toxins. However, natural compounds are "designed" by nature to interact with biological systems, either in a good way or a bad way. If a natural compound is not obviously bad, it is probably good, or at least not harmful. The same cannot be said of artificial compounds, which may have subtle effects. So, on that basis. natural IS better. However, it may be more important how the compound is processed and packaged (i.e., possibly with traces of very bad substances) than the source (artificial or natural) of the main substance. Using well-known major brandnames is the only even partial insurance of careful processing and packaging. > [...] Rating: 5.0 Product: Navitas Organics Chia Seed Powder, 8 oz. Bag Review: MY EXPERIENCE > I was intrigued by the promise of tapioca-like pudding which didn't have to be cooked. I love tapioca, but it is just too much work. I was somewhat disappointed with the chia pudding. There is a vague similarity between chia pudding and tapioca pudding, but chia pudding simply is not tapioca. > Chia pudding is more of a bland yogurt-like substance, which goes better with fresh fruit (berries, bananas, peaches, etc.) than alone. Indeed, my impression from the internet is that chia pudding (made with almond milk, soy milk, or water) is most popular among vegans, and is essentially used as "vegan yogurt". But, if you aren't vegan, your chia pudding doesn't have to be vegan. Chia pudding made with milk is tasty and appealing, particularly with fruit. MY RECIPE > For a thin yogart-like texture 2 tablespoons chia. For pudding-like texture, 3 tablespoons chia. 1 cup milk. This can be cow milk, probably even half-and-half, but vegans use almond milk, soy milk, or even coconut milk. Other reviewers claim that fruit juices can be used. > 1/4 to 1/2 teaspoons vanilla. > 1 teaspoon sugar (or agave, honey, etc.) to taste. Stevia works well if you want to minimize the sugar. Kal Pure Stevia Extract Powder -- 3.5 oz > Mix and chill overnight. The easiest way is to use a container with a tight lid so that you can shake it once an hour for the first several hours, so that the chia seeds fully hydrate. PS: EASY TAPIOCA PUDDING. My research on the internet revealed that tapioca pearls and pudding are two different things. Pudding (of any kind) is simply starch. For a 2-cup pudding mix, use 1/4 cup of tapioca pearls which have been soaking in dairy, soy or almond milk for at least 3 hours. If you use a vanilla or coconut pudding mix that you cook until it thickens, cook the hydrated tapioca pearls with the mix. Tapioca pearls in a vegan pudding would be vegan. Bob's Red Mill Tapioca, Small Pearl, 24-Ounce Units (Pack of 4) ;Jell-O Cook & Serve Pudding & Pie Filling, Coconut, 3-Ounce Boxes (Pack of 24) ;Bird's Custard Powder 300g. Coconut pudding and Bird's Custard mix contain no eggs, and so would be vegan, if made with soy or almond milk. Rating: 5.0 Product: Planters Deluxe Mixed Nuts - 40 oz. container - Value pack Review: The nuts are great (when fresh) BUT: is NOT a bargain (at $20 plus shipping, the price at the time of this writing) for two reasons: 1) BJ's sells the 40oz Planters Deluxe Mixed Nuts for $12.95, and offers $1 to $2.50 off coupons almost every month---so the real BJ's price is $9.45 to 11.95. At the time of this writing, Amazon offers 3 10-oz cans of Deluxe Mixed Nuts (the same product) for $10.05 (w free shipping on >$25 orders) which is a much better deal. For the same about $20 you'd get 6 cans = 60 ozs, which would stay fresh until opened. 2) The last half of the container will be stale, unless you eat the entire 40 ounces within about a week. I repackage the nuts into about 5 1-cup size glass jars with tight tops, and refrigerate. Recommendation: After major grocery shopping expeditions, sit down at your computer with your reciept, and check if you can buy any of the non-perishables through Amazon. When you find items (even if more expensive than you just paid), put the item on your Amazon wish list, and add a note to the wish list of the price you just paid. Check your wish list frequently, and when you see an item you need at a bargain price, buy it. Rating: 5.0 Product: Blue Diamond Almonds, Whole Natural, 1.5 Ounce (Pack of 24) Review: "Blue Diamond Whole Natural Almonds" are excellent unroasted and unsalted almonds. But, if (like me) you prefer the flavor of roasted and lightly-salted almonds, they simply are not as tasty as roasted, lightly-salted almonds. MORE HEALTHY than LIGHTLY-ROASTED LIGHTLY-SALTED ALMONDS? LIGHTLY ROASTED VS UNROASTED > Thorough roasting makes almonds more digestable. > Unroasted almonds (like peanuts) are susceptable to fungus which can be carcinogenic. > While commercial domestic almonds sold in the US do not contain significant levels of cyanide, bitter almonds do. Bitter almonds have a much richer almond flavor, particular in baked goods. Indeed natural almond extract is made from bitter almonds---artificial almond extract is safer. Bitter almonds are sometimes illegally sold in the US and are often encountered in other countries, and do contain dangerous levels of cyanide when raw. 7-10 raw bitter almonds can kill a child. Moreover, a child raised on raw ordinary almonds may conclude that raw peach pits (essentially a variety of almonds) or bitter almonds bought for cooking are safe to eat---they are NOT. The safest practice is NOT to eat unroasted almonds. LIGHTLY SALTED VS UNSALTED Humans crave salt because it is essential for human health. True, most commercially processed foods contain salt, and if you live on high-salt commercial foods, you may be getting too much salt. But, if you eat even moderately healthy (mostly fruits, vegetables, and fresh meat), there is nothing "bad" about a few salted almonds. VALUE Blue Diamomd roasted, salted, almonds of any variety are special: fresh, crunchy, and delicious. However there is NOTHING special about Blue Diamond unroasted unsalted almonds. 5-pound bags of generic unsalted unroasted almonds which I bought for cooking (at BJ's) are just as flavorful, for a fraction of the price of Blue Diamond. > Click on Stoney just below the product title to see my other reviews, or leave a comment to ask a question. Rating: 3.0 Product: Colavita Extra Virgin Olive Oil, 33.8 fl oz Review: QUALITY In my opinion, having used a dozen or so brands of olive oil, Colavita is simply the best reasonably-priced olive oil which is widely available. I've been using Colavita for several years now, and have never been disappointed. Colavita is excellent quality, dependable, and reasonably priced---the perfect combination for a daily general purpose olive oil. FLAVOR Although not an "olive oil gourmand", I'd describe Colavita as "rich, smooth, and neutral". Gourmands probably have other silly terms for the flavor, such as "fruity" (but a "civilian" would never call it fruity). It is NOT harsh or bitter like most common olive oil, NOT spicy like Whole Foods 360, and NOT "herby-fishy". Colavita is an evoo ("extra virgin olive oil"---to us non-olive oil snobs), which means "first pressing". Most olive-oil nuts consider the words "extra virgin" to be sacred. Practically speaking though, the mere label "extra virgin" is not a guarantee of quality---most grocery store brands (evoo or not) are harsh and bitter, but some are good cooking oils. PREMIUM OILS Botique premium oils are are as variable year to year as wines, comparably expensive, and have to be bought the way you buy fine wine (that is, ideally at tastings, where you confirm the quality and flavor before purchase). Some are genuinely (as in NOT-gourmet-speak) buttery and nutty---great for dipping. Some taste like the fragrance of flowers---great for salads. Never cook premium olive oil---use it for dipping or drizzling, or on delicate salads. Colavita is a good general purpose oil, better than most grocery store olive oil, but is not a premium oil. COOKING OIL Non-extra virgin olive oils (second or later pressings) are usually darker and stronger flavored---which adds complexity to soups, sauces, stews, bean dishes etc. If you are using a bitter or strong-tasting olive oil, cook it WITH the dish. I add 1/4 to 1/2 cup of olive oil to every sauce, soup, stew, chili, casserole, or bean dish, etc. However, olive oil can "go bad"---so unless you use alot, it doesn't sense to use a different cooking oil than you use on salads, for dipping etc. Colavita is a very good general purpose oil, and therefore a good cooking oil, but probably not the best choice for a restaurant which uses large quantities of olive oil. DIPPING OIL Traditionally (and in the best restaurants), Italian bread, oil and balsamic vinegar is served as an appetizer. The diner usually mixes his own oil and vinegar at the table. If all three are top quality, the combination can be delicious, and can even be a light meal. Add figs or slices of apple or pear and some olives, and you do have a meal. Albeit probably heresy, in fact you can substitute fine wine vinegar or fresh lemon juice. If I don't have olives, I usually add soy sauce or Braggs for saltiness to the mixture. Bragg Liquid Aminos, Natural Soy Sauce Alternative, 32-Ounce Bottle , (Pack of 3). Colavita is a very good "everyday" dipping oil. SALAD OIL The requirements for an "everyday" salad oil are a little less stringent than that for a dipping oil, because the heavy flavor of the vinegar, and often Parmesan, bacon bits, etc. usually dominate. However, I rarely prepare use oil and vinegar the traditional way. For everyday salads (or as a dip for raw vegies) I prefer olive-oil based mayo with a little freshly ground pepper, and some citrus zest. For special salads, I use a fruity premium olive oil (and just a hint of lemon and/or orange juice and zest). Colavita is a very good "everyday" salad oil. DRIZZING OIL A drizzling oil is an oil you pour over a dish immediately before serving, or which you serve in a carafe on the table. If you REALLY like the flavor of "ordinary good" olive oil (I don't)---then you will find Colavita to be a good drizzling oil. My hispanic wife frequently drizzles Colavita on the dishes I've cooked (with Colavita), because she likes the olive-oil flavor. By the way, the same principle applies to the use of butter, pepper, garlic, cheese, even soy sauce---if you want the flavor to dominate, add it just before serving; if you want the flavor to be subtle, cook the seasoning with the dish. For most dishes I prefer a rich blend of subtle flavors. HEALTHY COOKING I go to a great deal of effort to minimize animal fat in my diet, by very strict trimming, thorough cooking, and by chilling broth to remove the solidified fat. However, the body needs fat and craves fat. The ideal solution is to replace animal fat with vegetable oils which are high in omega-3s. Olive oil is ideal for the purpose. My Southern grandmother could not cook any vegetables without a thick slice of fatback (fatty bacon)---and indeed her vegetables were very tasty. Speaking of which, what is the point of healthy vegetables if no-one will eat them? The solution is to add several tablespoon fulls of olive oil, and a teaspoon of chipped ham Hormel Premium Real Crumbled Bacon to the vegies. For the best flavor, cook the vegies with the olive oil (do NOT add oil to the cooked vegetables---unless you really like the flavor of the oil). Season as necessary with pepper and fresh lemon juice. Truly delicious vegetables are possible---I eat them daily. ECONOMY The 34 ounce tins is about half the price of the bottle per oz at this time, but is expensive compared to the last time I purchased it. The tins are small enough to use directly. But I prefer bottles, because controlling the flow of the oil is easier (since you can see the oil approaching the spout), and it is easier to gauge the amount of oil I'm using by eye (how far the level drops in the glass bottle). So, I refill bottles from the tins. I've been told that olive oil stays fresher in tins (measured in months and years) That becomes relevant when you don't know how many months (or even years) a bottle may have sat on a grocery shelf. GENERAL RECOMMENDATION After major grocery shopping expeditions, sit down at your computer with your receipt, and check if you can buy any of the non-perishables through Amazon. When you find items (even if more expensive than you just paid), put the item on your Amazon wish list, and add a note to the wish list of the price you just paid. Check your wish list frequently, and when you see an item you need at a bargain price, buy it. > Click on Stoney just below the product title to see my other reviews, or leave a comment to ask a question. Rating: 5.0 Product: SweetLeaf Stevia Powder, 4-Ounce Shaker Jars (Pack of 2) Review: A TRUE REPLACEMENT After 60 years, I've broken my sugar addiction. Before pure Stevia, I used Splenda and later Truvia/Purevia (Stevia cut with bulking agents) for several years. The Truvia/Purevia were better than Splenda, but both the Splenda and Truvia/Purevia left disgusting residues and just didn't taste right (because of the fillers or bulking agents added). More importantly for me, I could not fully enjoy my gourmet coffee with either. When I first began using pure Stevia, I appreciated the better flavor and lack of a residue, but it still did not taste quite like sugar to me. However, after 6 months of pure Stevia, it tastes like sugar to me, and I am again enjoying gourmet coffee. Perhaps more precisely, pure stevia is "as effective" as sugar for "cutting the edge" of bitter or sour drinks and foods---the way most people use sugar. However, it is not as intensely sugary-sweet, regardless of how much you use. For a rare, once-a-month "desert" cup of fine coffee, I still use real sugar and real cream. Caveat: I find Splenda to be taste better in lemonade. COMPARISON TO KAL PURE STEVIA EXTRACT SWEETLEAF STEVIA POWDER contains the natural fiber Inulin as a bulking agent. KAL STEVIA POWDER does not. The Inulin does not seem to affect the flavor nor leave a yucky residue (as do the nasty bulking agents in Truvia/Purevia). Possibly due to the Inulin, SWEETLEAF STEVIA POWDER dissolves easier than KAL STEVIA POWDER. Pure Stevia Extract Powder - 3.5 oz - Powder CAUTION Inulin is a polysaccaride sometimes used as a sugar substitute itself (for diabetics). It has about 1/4 to 1/3 the sweetness of sugar, and about 1/4 to 1/3 the caloric content---which I interpret to mean the same calories for the same sweetness (however, in this case much of the sweetness is contributed by the Stevia). Inulin is a current food fad, with the usual (probably greatly exaggerated) claims of benefits, including improving digestion, reducing cholesterol, particularly triglycerides, protection from intestinal cancer, etc. On the otherhand, it causes digestive problems in some people. I suggest reading the Wikipedia article. If (like me), you don't have digestive problems with inulin, and it sounds as though the various benefits may be significant for your particular health problems---I suggest arranging for blood tests after a month of using inulin, and a month after not using inulin to compare. I used Sweetleaf Stevia for 6 months, and noticed no benefits, and my blood tests showed no improvement. Perhaps coincidentally, I did nave a digestive-related problem, and my liver function was worse. So, I returned to KAL Stevia. Perhaps coincidentally, after three months, the digestive-related problem has not re-occured and my liver function has improved (as measured by blood tests). I don't know if the inulin caused me any problems, but I do not believe it was any benefit. EASE OF USE SWEETLEAF STEVIA POWDER and KAL LIQUID STEVIA are easier to measure than KAL STEVIA POWDER, because the KAL STEVIA POWDER is much more concentrated. However, the KAL STEVIA POWDER comes with a tiny spoon which I find works perfectly well for measuring stevia for my coffee. However, the KAL STEVIA POWDER is so concentrated that it is difficult to sprinkle over a sliced fruit dish. Pure Stevia Liquid Extract - 4 oz - Liquid SWEETLEAF STEVIA POWDER dissolves easier than KAL STEVIA POWDER. That is not a problem for hot drinks, but SWEETLEAF STEVIA POWDER or KAL LIQUID are preferable for cold drinks, such as iced tea or lemonade. I also find that unsweetened fruit cups etc. are just too sour for my taste---a few drops of the KAL LIQUID STEVIA makes them perfect. ECONOMY $15.22 for 2 4oz bottles of SWEETLEAF STEVIA POWDER versus $18.44 for 1 3.5 oz of KAL STEVIA POWDER (the price at the time of this writing, both with free shipping on orders >$25) may seem a bargain, but the KAL STEVIA POWDER is much more concentrated. A 3.5oz jar of KAL STEVIA POWDER claims to hold 2381 servings. A 4oz bottle of SWEETLEAF STEVIA POWDER claims to hold 230 servings (= 460 servings for 2 bottles). The economy of KAL LIQUID is probably similar to SWEETLEAF STEVIA POWDER. I use "3 servings" per mug of strong coffee, so 1 bottle (3.5oz) of KAL STEVIA POWDER = 600 mugs of coffee, to my taste; while 2 bottles (8 oz) of SWEETLEAF STEVIA = 153 mugs of coffee. So, the KAL STEVIA POWDER is clearly the winner for pure economy, but even the SWEETLEAF STEVIA is far cheaper and superior to Truvia/Purevia. CONCLUSION For coffee and other hot drinks, KAL POWDER is the most economical. For cold drinks, fruit etc. SWEETLEAF POWDER (or KAL LIQUID) is more convenient. General Recommendation: After major grocery shopping expeditions, sit down at your computer with your receipt, and check if you can buy any of the non-perishables through Amazon. When you find items (even if more expensive than you just paid), put the item on your Amazon wish list, and add a note to the wish list of the price you just paid. Check your wish list frequently, and when you see an item you need at a bargain price, buy it. > Click on Stoney just below the product title to see my other reviews, or leave a comment to ask a question. Rating: 5.0 Product: Lindsay Olives Green Ripe Medium Pitted, 6-Ounce (Pack of 6) Review: I LOVE ripe green olives, but do not often buy them, because I cannot eat less than a can at a time. Lindsay olives are what they are: Very distinct from typical American stuffed queen olives. No vinegar. Only slightly salty. With a mild nutty flavor. To me, they most closely resemble ripe black olives---but milder. If you like olives but are on a low-salt diet, and perhaps mostly use them in salads, or even sliced on pizza, Lindsay Olives are terrific, as is the price. For a delicious spread, microwave cream cheese for about 1 minute in a ~24 oz glass bowl (such as Marinex 23.7-Ounce Small Round Casserole with Lid) to soften it, then mix-in coarsely chopped Lindsay Green Ripe olives. To make a dip, add a tablespoon of milk and mix. For snacking, or as a light meal with cheese and fruit, Lindsay Pitted Ripe Green Olvies are a faint shadow of the truly wonderful genre of "California ripe green olives". Unfortunately, the only brand you are likely to find outside California is Grabers olives,Graber Olives Size 14 7.5 oz. Can. Grabers are the Rolls Royce of ripe green olives, and are priced accordingly. About $1.50 per olive including shipping to the East Coast, perhaps $1 per olive if you buy them by the case directly from Grabers. What's the difference? Bigger, better olives to begin with, PITS, and careful processing. The pits make a huge difference in any olive---they impart a nutty flavor to the flesh. In the case of Grabers, the flaver is nutty and buttery. If you want to impress your guests at a buffet, serve Grabers---and go for the big size 16 olives. They'll cost you about $2 each (i.e., per olive), but are worth it. Unfortunately, Lindsay does not sell unpitted olives. I also recommend Byzantine Fresh Olive Antipasto, 5-Pound Bag and Byzantine Pitted Country Olive Mix, 5-Pound Bag Both are nice mixes of unpitted olives, without hot-peppers or other excessive flavoring. > Click on Stoney just below the product title to see my other reviews, or leave a comment to ask a question. These are chips and not shreds, and at first I was a bit at a loss about what I'd use them for. But then I made 'granola cereal' from them. We are grain-free so I followed a recipe that uses nuts and seeds and coconut to simulate a granola cereal. I can't even begin to describe the exquisite contribution this coconut made to the dish! When toasted it couldn't have tasted more like fresh coconut. It had a sweet, soft bite. I've since toasted them and used them on garnish on full-sugar cake and cupcakes that I've made for others. This goes WAY beyond generic "Angel Flake Coconut" you find in the store. This makes it look like you made it yourself.

I will buy this again and again!

Review:

But-----to me the Penzey's tasted just like the big jugs of Tone's restaurant-quality bulk vanilla. (Forget the claims of 2x strength, it's really not as good as the Nielsen-Massey) This brand has been my favorite for 15 years.

Normally I bought this at Williams-Sonoma, but was pleased to find it MUCH cheaper on Amazon! The price here is beyond reasonable, what do you have to lose by trying it? If you are like me and have tried endless vanillas, see how this one works for you!

Review:
The price of this item is better than even the no-name coconut at our local health food store. I found the grind size to be just right for my microwave muffins. We are doing low carb and this coconut product is very versatile for so many recipes. it's about rice-sized.

If you want coconut flour just run this through your food processor or coffee grinder (not one you make coffee beans in) and you have instant flour for thickening or coating or recipes.

I recently discovered this coconut product is ideal to make coconut shrimp! Just use this instead of flour in your egg/flour wash before you fry your shrimp. Watch carefully as it browns in a hurry! Pulse some coconut with some peanut flour (Protein Plus or PB2) and use that as your dredge, it makes THE crispiest, sweetest coating!

It goes from brown to burned in seconds so keep the heat low and slow. Stir a lot.
If you have liquid Splenda you can make a mock Angel Flake coconut with it! (I prefer Ideal sweetener but you have to make a simple syrup with it and water to get the same effect)
Love this product, I've tried a lot of crappy coconut over the years and as long as this is fresh when you get it, you can't get anything better!

As a hot drink, this cider is simply wonderful!

Product:
Harmony House Foods Soup Mix, Italian Vegetable Soup, 14 Ounce Quart Size Jar
Review:
This is a good soup blend.  My only reservation is with the kidney beans.  I was able to cook them until they were tender, but the skin or outer layer of the beans remained tough and chewy.  Not inedible, just chewier than I felt they should be.  Everything else in the mix was good.  I brought 4 cups of chicken broth to a boil, then added a cup of the soup mix and a cup of pasta shells... brought it to a boil again, covered the pot, then let it simmer for about 30 minutes (it was a low simmer).  The veggies added more flavor to the chicken broth, and I didn't have to add any other seasonings (though you could).  Next time, I'll use vegetable broth for more of a "minestrone" flavor -- might also try to slow cooker method.

Overall, I'm very satisfied with the product and would definitely order from Harmony House again.  As a matter of fact, I'm kind of eyeballing their dehydrated cabbage. Mmmm, cabbage soup...

If you're cooking for one or two people, like I am, this is nice change of pace from a can of condensed soup.  You can make just enough for one, or a huge pot for a small army.  You control the ratio of broth to veggies, you can add leftover chicken, pasta, rice... and not have to chop veggies all morning.

Oh, I should also mention (my own preference), I specifically chose this soup mix because it had no peppers (green or red) and contained cabbage.

Rating: 5.0 Product: Albanese Candy, Mini Gummi Butterflies, 7.5-Ounce Bag, Pack of 12 Review: I've been buying Haribo for years, and swear by everyone of their candies. The texture is more chewy than Haribo as well, but the taste is missing something. More than anything, these gummy bears have a sweet tarty (not like Sweet tarts, just sweet and tarty, and a mild flavor) taste. I noticed that these are getting generally great reviews, and I wish I could have had the same experience. Overall, I like the price on these, as they are reasonably priced, but I prefer Haribo. *** on a side note, the purple ones (I'm guessing grape) tastes the best, although my pack had mostly orange and red. The purples had a nice flavor, and I'd rate the purple as a 5 star product, although IN MY OPINION, the others weren't as good. *** on another side note, I gave this gummy candy to others, and many of them actually said that this was better than the Haribo, and they liked the fact that this was chewier. so, just because it isn't to my liking doesn't mean that this isn't a five star product. it's all a matter of preference I guess. Product:
Eight O Clock, Hazelnut, Single-Serve Keurig K-Cup Pods, Medium Roast Coffee, 96 Count (4 Boxes of 24 Pods)
Review:
I prefer dark roast bc I put dairy in my coffee and the taste needs to hold up to that, and this does.  Some dark roasts are just not strong enough to do that, I try new ones and have come to like other brands, but there are many out there not worth buying again.  I would try this if you like dark roast.
Rating:
5.0
Product:
Copper Moon Single Cups for Keurig K-Cup Brewers, Kenyan, 20 Count, Medium Roast Coffee, Bold and Chocolatey, with Finishing Hints of Hazelnut, Single-Serve Coffee Pods
Review:
Taste is a personal matter I suppose. I liked the Keurig Kona when it was offered, so I tried one box of this Kona to see if it's one I would take to. I don't like it as much as the Kona I remember, that's all I can say.  It has a bitter or burnt afternote to me, one that I do not care for. I am one for Tully's Italian and Starbucks Verona and the Sumatra coffee beans, they all taste smooth to me and not bitter at all.  Yes, this doesn't seem like a medium roast, more toward a dark roast to me, but I like dark roast bc I put dairy in my coffee...so it's not that that I am concerned about, it's the taste in general.
Rating:
3.0
Product:
Copper Moon Single Cups for Keurig K-Cup Brewers, Kenyan, 20 Count, Medium Roast Coffee, Bold and Chocolatey, with Finishing Hints of Hazelnut, Single-Serve Coffee Pods
Review:
Excellent coffee, not bitter, just plain good.  I found it in The Christmas Tree Shoppes, sold in boxes of 12 for $6.99.  If you get a good price for it, try it.  I use dairy in my coffee, so I like a 'dark roast' and this is dark roast. If you like something milder, try their Costa Rican variety, it's a medium roast.
Rating:
5.0
Product:
Torani Toasted Hazelnut Flavored Coffee, Single Serve Cups for Keurig K Cups Brewer, 24 Count
Review:
Excellent taste, not bitter, smooth.  It is like Keurig's Tully's Italian which is one of my top 3 faves.  I use the larger, 8 oz cup setting on my Keurig machine for each one of these servings. Then I add some dairy to my coffee. I always buy 'dark' roast bc I do dilute it w/dairy, and this is one that I would buy again.
Rating:
5.0
Product:
Tully's Coffee Italian Roast, 24-Count K-Cups for Keurig Brewers (Pack of 2)
Review:
I have been taste-testing so many brands and roasts of k-cups to determine our favorites that I feel like a 'lab rat.'  The Tully's Italian Roast immediately stood out from the rest--love at first sip! The other reviews are accurate by describing it as aromatic, smooth and flavorful, not bitter nor weak. I make my first cup of the morning by using one k-cup on the large cup setting, then I make my add'l cups of coffee using one k-cup and a combination of both the middle and smallest cup; that way I get more coffee using one K-cup. It still holds a robust flavor but just not as heavily as the first, which is what I like to do after drinking sev'l cups.  I use cream & sugar, so this routine works for me.  You may or may not tend to tweak your ritual the same way, but it just goes to show you that you can "think out of the k-cup."
Rating:
5.0
Product:
International Delight, French Vanilla, Single-Serve Coffee Creamers, 24 Count (Pack of 6), Shelf Stable Non-Dairy Flavored Coffee Creamer, Great for Home Use, Offices, Parties or Group Events
Review:
We are heading to Italy in Sept and bringing our coffeemaker and these mini moos along! I bought these at Sam's, for half the price, so FYI.  The expiration date is 3 months from now, early Dec.  I don't think these items ever are more than 3 months expiration.  That is the nature of the beast.  It cannot last months and months up to a year b/c it is real dairy. If you get these with an expiration time frame of 2 or so months to use up, as others have 'complained' of, then you are in the ballpark. What I like about this product vs. others that came before it, is that this is the real deal which is so much better than imitation non-dairy creamer substitutes.
Rating:
5.0
Product:
Timothy's World Coffee Canarino, Italian Hot Lemon Beverage, K-Cups for Keurig Brewers, 25-Count Boxes (Pack of 2)
Review:
First off, I am an avid coffee drinker, only drinking tea when I eat out at Chinese restaurants or am under the weather--then I will only drink decaf green tea. I also like the taste of lemon. I may not be a bonafide tea drinker, but I know what I like. That being said, upon receiving a sample box of Canarino and having a cough/cold this week, I tried the Canarino instead of my usual go-to green tea. I loved it! What a nice change of pace. It wasn't bitter whatsoever to my taste. I sipped it w/o honey or sugar. I used the 8oz. serving cup size, just fine. It was smooth and light and kept my throat moist and was very comforting. It reminded me of Thera-flu w/out all the added medicinals. When I'm over this cold, I just might try it with a little added splash of my Limoncello!
Rating:
5.0

prompt.content:

Product:
Mariani Sun Ripened Mixed Fruit No Sugar Added Dried Fruit 36 Ounce Value Bag
Review:
Italian Plums have always been used to make prunes. When allowed to ripen on the vine (tree), these plums are out of this world. The skin of this beautiful dark purple and oval-shaped plum contains very sweet, slightly firm flesh surrounding a small seed that doesn't cling. All this is what makes for a delicious prune when dried.

I noted the other fruits do come from other countries, but so do many of the fresh fruits we purchase in markets and we usually don't know where they came from.

I can't imagine that dried fruit from Costco would necessarily be a better product, especially if it's a house brand. I've noticed lately that some of their products have deteriorated in quality, i.e., baby wipes, bath tissues, to name a couple.
Rating:
4.0
Product:
Hungarian Sweet Paprika, 5-Ounce Tins (Pack of 6)
Review:
I was in the middle of making chicken paprikash and noticed that my can of Szeged Sweet Paprika was getting low. When I checked my last purchase on Amazon it was no longer available from that vendor. I paid $8.40 for a 5 oz. can, which really turned out to be fortunate for me -- I frantically started checking for another vendor of Hungarian Paprika and came across this terrific bargain. Even though Prime doesn't apply to this, I'm only paying $30.00 for 6 cans. Since I use 1/4 cup per recipe, I'll probably go through that amount fairly quickly.

Imported to the US directly from Kalocsa Paprika Ltd., Kalocsa, this Szeged Sweet Paprika is an absolute necessity if you plan on making authentic Hungarian Chicken Paprikash.
Rating:
5.0
Product:
Torani Sugar Free Syrup, Coconut, 33.8 Ounce (Pack of 3)
Review:
The product is great. I really enjoy the brown sugar and cinnamon in my oatmeal and have been using it for quite some time now. Each time I purchased it in the past it was sold and shipped by Amazon at $23.91 for 3 bottles. Torani, in most flavors, is sold locally at $4.99 for a 33.8 oz. bottle. Unfortunately, none of the local stores have started carrying this flavor yet, so I figured that paying Amazon $7.97 per bottle shipped with my Prime wasn't such a bad deal. Now Amazon has a third party selling it for $29.65 per 3 bottles, plus $8.91 for shipping. $12.85 per bottle is just a little more than I'm willing to pay for something I can order directly from the Torani people.

Update: 09/23/2013:
Sellers may actually pay attention to reviews **SURPRISE** as the price for this product came down from $29.65 yesterday to $24.99 + shipping @ $13.75 today. Too late, though, since I purchased it directly from Torani yesterday for $22.05 + shipping @ $6.95.
Rating:
3.0
Product:
NuSci Aspartame Pure Powder 227 grams (8.0 oz) Low Calorie Sweetener
Review:
This is really wonderful. I have been using it in drinks, tea, coffee and anything else that I want sweetened, including cooking with it. I mix it in my oatmeal before microwaving -- so delicious. Up until now I've been using Equal, but its first ingredient is Dextrose w/Maltodextrin (sugar) which, in my opinion, defeats the purpose of using it. Can't tell the difference between using the pure Aspartame powder or using Equal.

The only thing I wish NuSci would do is to pack it directly in a glass or plastic jar. It takes some dexterity to transfer from the plastic package. It is so much easier to use by "spooning" it out of a jar. As for the packaging itself, I must admit is excellent. The powder is in a heavy plastic zipped bag with the label on it, which is then placed into another heavy zipped plastic bag.
Rating:
5.0
Product:
Equal 0 Calorie Sweetener, Granulated 4 oz (Pack of 8)
Review:
I notice that a number of people giving a one-star rating say it is not as sweet as what is in Equal packets. The reason for that may be because Equal packets contain Dextrose, Maltodextrin, Aspartame and Acesulfame Potassium. Equal Spoonful contains Maltodextrin, Aspartame, Acesulfame Potassium -- it doesn't have Dextrose in it. Dextrose is sugar (actually a simple sugar) which also helps dissolve the product more quickly.

In the past I have purchased pure Aspartame from Amazon (NuSci Aspartame Pure Powder 227 grams (8.0 oz) Low Calorie Sweetener) which is quite difficult to dissolve and it too has a different taste. However, it's good if you want plain Aspartame.

I have been using Equal for  50 years and for the information of anyone terrified of Aspartame, I don't have any of the diseases with which quacks insist on threatening people who do use it.
Rating:
4.0
Product:
York Sugar Free Peppermint Patties Dark Chocolate Covered Mint Candy, 3 Ounce (Pack of 12)
Review:
Maltitol, Lactitol, Isomalt and Sorbitol -- the sugar substitutes used in this product can be pure poison to some individuals.  I am one of those people.  Granted, the makers of this product warn it can have a laxative effect (that's from the above-mentioned sugar substitutes, not the product itself), but some of us go way beyond experiencing a laxative effect to debilitating diarrhea even with moderate consumption of cookies or candies made with these sugar substitutes.
Rating:
1.0
Product:
Szeged Hungarian Paprika, Sweet, 5 Ounce
Review:
I am cleaning out my spice cabinet and came across this identical can of Szeged Rose Paprika at the very back. The only difference I can see between mine and the picture on here is the top. Mine is white with 3 ways to open -- sift, spoon or pour -- and all are very difficult to open. This can is very old, decades, and I was trying to figure out why it is still here. I suppose it's nostalgia because I certainly wasn't using it. Occasionally over the years I have tried to find this product and couldn't. I decided to Google it and arrived here. After reading the reviews, I realize why it wasn't being used. It is a very dark red and has a bitter, not sweet, taste. I have purchased other brands and been disappointed. None of them met the standards of the one my mother used which is why I kept trying to find this brand, hoping I just got a bad batch. I am going to purchase a can and see what I end up with this time.

BTW, no bugs and if there were, they certainly would have had decades to do their thing.
Rating:
2.0

Product:
Pastariso Instant Rice Mac and Cheese Meal Cup, 2 Ounce (Pack of 6)
Review:
I wasn't expecting much from the Pastariso Instant Rice Mac and Cheese Meal Cup, and that is pretty much what I got.
It would have actually been better than expected except for the fact that the product's cardboard container makes it taste like, you guessed it, cardboard. Preparation was easy and fast. I did not have any issues with it spilling in my microwave, or coming out "soupy" and unevenly cooked. The gluten free rice macaroni was actually better than expected, and the cheese sauce came out well after letting the product sit for a minute. Unfortunately, there's no getting past the cardboard taste. It doesn't make the Pastariso Instant Rice Mac and Cheese Meal Cup inedible, but it makes it just bad enough to not recommend it.
Rating:
3.0
Product:
Barilla Organic Pasta, Spaghetti & Penne, 16 Ounce (Pack of 6)
Review:
Barilla Organic Pasta, Spaghetti & Penne is made from certified USDA Organic ingredients, and contains no GMO ingredients. This variety pack contains 3 boxes of USDA Organic Spaghetti Pasta and 3 boxes of Organic Penne Pasta. The pasta cooks up al dente, and has the same texture and great taste of regular Barilla Pasta. I enjoyed it.
Rating:
5.0
Product:
Wholesome Organic Pancake Syrup, Non GMO, 20 fl oz (Pack of 6)
Review:
Wholesome Sweeteners Organic Pancake Syrup is a good tasting pancake syrup, but the best part is that it doesn't contain high fructose corn syrup. Honestly, I have no idea how much healthier organic cane sugar syrup really is, but I do know how bad high fructose corn syrup is. My doctor calls it  "evil". On his advice,  I've eliminated most of it from my diet, and lost 20 pounds in 6 months. I feel better too.

Wholesome Sweeteners Organic Pancake Syrup is a nice thick syrup, almost the consistency of maple syrup. It isn't quite as good as maple syrup though, but I didn't expect it to be. It does tatse better than the usual store bought syrups, but also costs about twice as much. It costs less per ounce than maple syrup though. I like Wholesome Sweeteners Organic Pancake Syrup, and will use it in the future.
Rating:
4.0
Product:
Community Coffee Ground Coffee, Breakfast Blend, (Pack of 3)
Review:
Community Coffee Ground Coffee "Breakfast Blend" is a very good medium roast coffee made with 100% Arabica coffee beans. I generally do not like dark roasts, especially the blends found at most popular chain coffee houses. I also find light roasts to be bland and/or weak, so medium roasts are my blend of choice. Community Coffee Breakfast Blend  definitely falls in the category of medium roast, and I like it a lot. While there isn't anything really distinctive about the taste, it's just good coffee. If I had to compare it to another coffee, to me it tastes similar to McDonald's Premium Roast Coffee, which to me is also very good. Community Coffee Breakfast Blend isn't bitter. It's somewhat mellow but not weak, and very smooth. Medium roast fans should really like it. Light and dark roast drinkers probably won't hate it either.
Rating:
5.0
Product:
ACUTEfruit 8x24 Tropical Blast, 8-Ounce (Pack of 24)
Review:
ACUTEfruit Tropical Blast is non-carbonated fruit blend energy drink that unlike most energy drinks contains 50% fruit juice and only 70 calories. It also contains 3g of Fiber, and is loaded with B Vitamins. ACUTEfruit Tropical Blast  gets it's energy mostly from the small amount of caffeine (47mg) from Guarana and Yerba Mate. It does not provide the jolt that the mega caffeine, high sugar energy drinks provide. This can be a positive or a disappointment depending on what you're expecting. There is no "crash" after drinking ACUTEfruit Tropical Blast which is a major plus. Taste wise, I find the apple and orange juice combination to pleasant enough. I find canned orange juice to always have a strange taste with an almost medicine like after taste, and ACUTEfruit Tropical Blast has a little bit of that. The apple juice does a pretty good job of masking it though.

I like ACUTEfruit Tropical Blast. It gives me the same boost as a cup of coffee despite having less caffeine, and the ingredients are somewhat healthier than the average energy drink.
Rating:
4.0
Product:
Eight O'Clock Coffee, Original Ground, 12-Ounce Bag (Pack of 4)
Review:
Everyone has different tastes, but Eight O'Clock is my favorite coffee. It's a smooth, medium-mild blend. Drinkers of dark blend coffees will probably prefer 8 O'Clock 100% Columbian. It is stronger and bolder. Both are excellent coffees, and moderately priced.
Rating:
5.0
Product:
Balance Bar, Chocolate Caramel Peanut Nougat, 1.41 ounce bars 6 count, Chocolate Caramel Peanut Nougat Nutrition Bar
Review:
Balance Chocolate Peppermint Patty, 1.41 ounce bars are chewy candy bar like snacks that taste quite good, but I'm not a fan of the very chewy like texture. The bars are gluten and wheat free, and contain slightly less calories, sugar, and fat than a standard candy bar. They also contain some fiber too. Price wise, they cost about twice as much as a candy bar. In the end, Balance Chocolate Peppermint Patty, 1.41 ounce bars aren't bad. I can see people really enjoying them is they want a chewy candy bar like snack. To me though, I was expecting something a little different than what tastes like just another candy bar.
Rating:
3.0

Basically after drinking this for a few days, my arms legs and face began to tingle after being in the sunlight for even a few minutes.  I researched all the ingredients in this tea and turns out saint johns wort, which there are TWO types of it in this tea, is the culprit. prompt.content:
You are an Amazon customer that likes to write reviews for products. You will be provided a set of features to help you understand your writing style.
First feature you will receive is similar product-review pairs from your past reviews to remind you of your style:
<similarpairs>
Product:
Altoids Peppermint Mints - 6 paks
Review:
I've carried a tin of Altoids with me since I was a kid in grade school, well over sixty years ago.  Of course, the tin is what attracted me to the product but then I got hooked on the burst of peppermint in my mouth. There is something so old world soothing about opening the tin, gently parting the thin foldover paper, and choosing just one mint, refolding the paper and snapping the tin shut.  I've never gotten tired of that experience.

Altoids, the curiously strong mints, have not changed their recipe in over 200 years, using only natural flavors.  The explosion of peppermint when placed on the tongue is truly a treat which I'll never be without.  Refreshing experience from such a little lozenge.
And a delightful refresher after a meal without adding but a couple of calories.
Rating:
5.0
Product:
Harney & Sons Caffeinated Hot Cinnamon Sunset Black Tea with Orange and Cloves Tin 20 Sachets
Review:
This is a wonderful cinnamon spice flavored tea which is caffeinated.  I prefer the caffeinated for mornings and an herbal tea in the evenings.  I ran across the Sunset tea at my local Walmart at about half the price of Amazon so I purchased a tin of 20.  The bags are mesh in a pyramid shape, giving full brewing access to the tea.  I normally use a half teaspoon of honey in my teas but this particular tea doesn't require any extra sweetner.

I find that the tea bag is strong enough to brew a double cup as 8 oz. of water is just too little and makes quite a potent brew.  I keep an extensive variation of teas to suit my mood but find that this Harney and Sons Hot Cinnamon Sunset is one of my go to flavors.  As an added plus, the kitchen smells wonderful while the cup is steeping.  Even my husband comments on how good it smells and he's not a tea drinker.
Rating:
5.0
Product:
Mrs. Dash, Seasoning Blend, Onion & Herb, 2.5 Ounce
Review:
This product by Mrs. Dash is one of the better salt free blends in the product line.  I use several Mrs. Dash items and like to switch up the seasonings.  Too much pepper bothers me and this one particular blend doesn't have as much pepper in it as some other Mrs. Dash products although pepper is the third ingredient listed.  The onion and herb flavors are not over powering but of course, can be strengthened with a heavier application of it.

My household is not on a salt restriction diet but as we get older we try to cut down on it and the Mrs. Dash products give us lots of flavor without the salt, which then we use so much more sparingly.  I find the Onion and Herb flavors compliment pork really well and I like to use it on our vegetables.  We keep three of the Mrs. Dash mixtures on our spice shelf, the original being the most used.  It's a very good product that enhances the flavors of grilled meats and veggies.
Rating:
5.0
Product:
Keebler Club Crackers Original, 13.7 Oz. (Pack of 3)
Review:
A salad or a bowl of soup is just not complete without Keebler Club Crackers.  We have eaten these crackers for many years now and after trying out several brands and store brands, always come back to Keebler.  They are so light and tender with a buttery flavor and seem to just melt in our mouths.

I always have a box on hand and they stay fresh and crisp.  I roll down the top on a partially used sleeve of the crackers and gently put a rubber band lengthwise on it.  This has always worked, even in the hot humid summers. Keebler club crackers may cost a little more but are totally worth the extra expense.

These in no way resemble a saltine, which have their own place in the kitchen.  Yummy good.
Rating:
5.0
Product:
Betty Crocker, Muffin Mix, Authenic Cornbread & Muffin Mix, 6.5-Ounce Pouches (Pack of 6)
Review:
Betty Crocker cornbread mix is by far the best mix that I've found.  Most of the mixes I've tried are much too sweet and we don't care for a heavy sweetness when paired with ham and beans or homemade vegetable soup.  It is super easy as it only requires three ingredients to be added, milk, egg and butter.  It turns out light and tender and rises very well.  It has that wonderful cornbread taste that so many of the other mixes are lacking. I've tried many recipes through the years and have not found one that is better than this mix,  the recipes make way too much anyway and I have to throw the leftovers out for the birds.

I have a small cast iron skillet that I bake this in as it seems to be the perfect size and as the pan is old and well seasoned, the cornbread pops out without sticking.  I've also made muffins and cornbread sticks with it.  Actually it depends on what we're having with it that determines what pan I'll use.  The envelope makes just the right amount for the two of us and with enough left over for another meal.  If you have more than three or four in your family, you'll probably need to use two packets.
Rating:
5.0
Product:
Tone's Minced Onion - 15 oz shaker
Review:
I have had a large container of Tone's dried minced onion in my pantry supplies for years now and am constantly reaching for them.  If I'm making a big pot of soup or stew I'll use fresh onions but for small jobs, the dried onions are indispensable.  I love to put them in my tuna or chicken salads as they reconstitute with the available ground up sweet pickle juices and make a much nicer consistency of salads.

I find that the onion flavor is milder than fresh onions but that is one of the reasons why I like to use them, they're not overpowering.  And I really don't like the crunch of freshly chopped onion in my sandwiches and I hardly know they're in the recipe except for the subtle flavor.  These are also great to mix with ground beef when grilling hamburgers for when I don't have any fresh onions on hand to slice.

I find that they never spoil and keep their flavor indefinitely which is a big money saver as fresh onions can turn on me quite quickly no matter how I store them.  This large size container is so much more economical than a small bottle off the spice shelf. They reconstitute quickly in a little warm water if I should want to plump them up before using.  Great product!
Rating:
5.0
Product:
Hidden Valley Original Ranch Seasoning and Salad Dressing Mix, 16 Ounce
Review:
If you are like me and use Hidden Valley Ranch and Seasoning mix in much of your cooking, then this 16 oz. container is the only way to go.  I have found such a wide range of uses that are enhanced with this seasoning mix.  To name a few; our hearty Taco Soup that is a go to in the winter, sprinkled on cubed potatoes that are then oven browned, sprinkled over baked potatoes, sprinkled on popcorn, sprinkled on steamed broccoli and green beans, mixed with sour cream or plain yogurt for a tasty dip, the applications are as endless as your imagination.  And on occasion I do actually make a dressing for salads with this!  So simple and fresh tasting. I used to only buy the envelopes but as I found the bountiful ways to use it, I had to go with the bulk containers.  As I cannot find this larger container in my local Walmart, Amazon provides a great and economical place to get it.
Rating:
5.0

Rating:
